args.[-dm]: can be added to make the bot send the output to your DMs.

commands.description: Gives you information about the bot.

args.[channel]: can either be the name, a mention or the ID of a channel. Leave empty to use the channel the message was sent in.

notes: Commands will be disabled in the counting channel.

args.[module]: can be a name of a module you want to toggle. Leave empty to get a list of modules.

notes: Modules can be found further down on this page.

args.<count>: is the count you want to get notified of.

commands.description: Subscribe to a count in the guild.

args.[topic]: can be what you want to be displayed in the topic. Leave it empty to reset it. Set to 'disable' to disable it completely. If you use {{COUNT}} as a placeholder, you can customize it to however you want.

examples: topic Count to infinity, next count is {{COUNT}}, who gets it?

args.<count>: is whatever you want to set the count to.

commands.description: Set the count to a specific count.

args.<mode>: is where you define the mode. Setting it to "each" will set it to each <count>, ex. 1000 will accept 1000, 2000, 3000 etc. Setting it to "only" will set it to only be <count>.
args.<count>: is where you set the count that the bot will check on.
args.<duration>: is where you decide the duration. Setting it to "permanent" will make the role stay permanent on until it's removed manually. Setting it to "temporary" will only allow 1 person to have the role, aka. when someone gets the role, the other person gets kicked out of the role.
args.<role...>: is where you define the role. It can be either the name, mention or ID of the role.

commands.description: Set up a role prize so people can get roles when they count.
notes: Give Countr the Manage Roles-permission and have the Countr-role over the role(s) you want to be rewarded.

modules.description: This allows members to count more than once in a row, without someone else typing between.
This allows members to talk after the count, ex. '1337 hello Admin!'
This makes the bot repost the message, preventing the user to edit or delete the count afterwards.
This makes the reposted message be a webhook. (Requires the 'reposting'-module)
This makes the bot delete all new messages while it's been offline. In a nutshell, resumes the counting. This feature is BETA, so use it at your own risk.
